summary.long: 1 Kings is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: When King David was old and advanced in years, his servants covered him with blankets, but he could not get warm.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they said to him, “Let your servants search for a young woman, a virgin, for my lord the king. She will attend to the king and be his nurse. She will lie close to him and keep my lord the king warm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they searched the whole territory of Israel for a beautiful young woman. They found Abishag from Shunem and brought her to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young woman was very beautiful, and she served as the king’s nurse, but the king was not intimate with her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah son of Haggith was pushing himself forward, saying, “I will become king.” He obtained a chariot and charioteers and fifty men to run ahead of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
His father had never rebuked him by saying, “Why are you acting like this?”
Adonijah also was very handsome and had been born next in line after Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joab son of Zeruiah and Abiathar the priest conspired with Adonijah and gave him their support.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and Nathan the prophet, along with Shimei, Rei, and David’s elite warriors, did not join with Adonijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah sacrificed sheep, cattle, and specially fattened calves at the Stone of Zoheleth, which was near En Rogel Spring. He invited all of his brothers, the king’s sons, and all of the king’s officials from Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he did not invite the prophet Nathan, Benaiah, the elite warriors, or his brother Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said to Bathsheba, Solomon’s mother, “Haven’t you heard that Adonijah son of Haggith has become king, and our lord David does not know about it?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now let me give you some advice on how to save your life and the life of your son Solomon:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go to King David and say to him, ‘My lord the king, didn’t you swear to me your servant and promise me, “Your son Solomon will be king after me, and he will sit on my throne”? Then why has Adonijah become king?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, while you are still there speaking with the king, I will come in after you and confirm your words.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba went to the king in his chamber. The king was very old, and Abishag from Shunem was taking care of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba knelt and bowed down before the king. The king said, “Why have you come?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “My lord, you swore to your servant by the Lord your God and promised, ‘Your son Solomon will be king after me, and he will sit on my throne.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, look, Adonijah has become king, and you, my lord the king, did not know about it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He has sacrificed cattle, specially fattened calves, and sheep in abundance. He has invited all the king’s sons, as well as Abiathar the priest and Joab the commander of the army. But he has not invited your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, my lord the king, the eyes of all Israel are upon you, waiting for you to tell them who will sit on my lord the king’s throne after him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you do not, when my lord the king rests with his fathers, then I and my son Solomon will be treated like traitors.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then, while she was still speaking with the king, Nathan the prophet came in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king was told, “The prophet Nathan is here.” Nathan went in and bowed down to the ground before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nathan said, “Did you, my lord the king, say, ‘Adonijah will be king after me, and he will sit on my throne’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Today he has gone out and sacrificed a great many cattle, specially fattened calves, and sheep. He has invited all the king’s sons, the commanders of the army, and Abiathar the priest. They are even eating and drinking with him and saying, ‘Long live King Adonijah!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he has not invited me your servant, Zadok the priest, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, or your servant Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Has this command about who will sit on the throne of my lord the king after him really come from my lord the king, even though you have not made this known to your servants?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King David responded, “Call Bathsheba for me.” She came in and stood before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king swore, “As surely as the Lord lives, who has redeemed my life from every tight spot,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: just as I swore to you by the Lord, the God of Israel, that Solomon your son will be king after me and he will sit on my throne in my place, I will indeed make it happen this very day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba knelt down on the ground and bowed before the king and said, “May my lord King David live forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King David said, “Call in Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah son of Jehoiada.” So they came in before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to them, “Take your lord’s servants with you. Have my son Solomon ride on my own mule, and bring him down to Gihon Spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet are to anoint him as king over Israel. Then you are to blow the ram’s horn and say, ‘Long live King Solomon!’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then you are to follow him, as he goes in and sits on my throne, and he will be king in my place. I decree that he will be leader over Israel and Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Benaiah son of Jehoiada responded to the king, “Amen! May the Lord, the God of my lord the king, confirm this!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just as the Lord was with my lord the king, so may he also be with Solomon. May he make his throne greater than the throne of my lord King David!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites, and the Pelethites went out. They had Solomon ride on the mule that belonged to King David and brought him down to Gihon Spring.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zadok the priest took the horn of olive oil from the Tent and anointed Solomon. After that they blew the ram’s horn, and all the people said, “Long live King Solomon!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people followed Solomon. The people were playing flutes and rejoicing so greatly that the ground shook from the sound.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Adonijah and all his guests heard it, they stopped eating. Joab heard the sound of the ram’s horn and asked, “Why is the noise from the city so loud?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Just then, while he was still speaking, Jonathan, son of Abiathar the priest, came in. Adonijah said, “Come in, for you are a worthy man, and you must be bringing good news.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Jonathan responded to Adonijah:
Not at all! Our lord King David has made Solomon king!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king sent Zadok the priest, Nathan the prophet, Benaiah son of Jehoiada, the Kerethites, and the Pelethites with Solomon, and they placed him on the king’s mule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anointed him as king at Gihon, and they went up from there rejoicing. The city is in an uproar. That is the noise you have been hearing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, Solomon has taken his seat on the throne of the kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king’s servants have come to bless our lord King David, saying, “May your God treat the name of Solomon even more favorably than your name, and may his throne be greater than your throne.”
The king bowed in worship on his bed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the king spoke the following words: “Blessed be the Lord, the God of Israel, who today has provided someone to sit upon my throne and has permitted my eyes to see it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all of Adonijah’s guests quickly got up, and each one went his own way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adonijah was afraid of Solomon, so he went and held on to the horns of the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was told, “Adonijah is so afraid of King Solomon that he has grabbed the horns of the altar, and he is saying, ‘Let King Solomon swear to me this day that he will not kill his servant with the sword.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon said, “If he is a worthy man, not a hair of his head will fall to the ground, but if he is caught planning evil, he will die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Solomon had Adonijah brought down from the altar. He came in and bowed down to King Solomon, and Solomon told him, “Go to your house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The day of David’s death was approaching, so he gave the following commands to his son Solomon:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I am about to go the way of all the earth. Now, be strong and act like a man!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fulfill your duties to the Lord your God. Walk in his ways. Keep his statutes, his commands, his ordinances, and his decrees as they are written in the Law of Moses, so that you may have success in everything you do and everywhere you turn,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: in order that the Lord may keep this word that he spoke to me: “If your sons are careful to walk before me faithfully with their whole heart and soul, then you will never fail to have a man on the throne of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Furthermore, you know what Joab son of Zeruiah did to me—what he did to two commanders of the army of Israel, to Abner son of Ner and Amasa son of Jether. He killed them, spilling blood in peacetime as if it were happening in war. He spattered that blood on the belt around his waist and on the sandals on his feet, as if it were war.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Deal with him according to your wisdom, but do not let his gray hair go down to the grave in peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Keep faith with the sons of Barzillai from Gilead, and let them eat at your table, because they did the same for me when I fled from your brother Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Watch out for Shimei son of Gera from Bahurim of the tribe of Benjamin, since he is still with you. He cursed me bitterly on the day I went to Mahanaim. But when he came down to meet me at the Jordan, I swore to him by the Lord, “I will not kill you with the sword.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now, do not leave him unpunished, for you are a wise man. You will know what you should do to him. Bring his gray hair down to the grave in blood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David rested with his fathers and was buried in the City of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: David was king over Israel for forty years. He was king in Hebron for seven years, and he was king in Jerusalem for thirty-three years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was seated on the throne of his father David, and his kingship was firmly established.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Adonijah son of Haggith came to Solomon’s mother Bathsheba. She said to him, “Do you come in peace?”
“Yes, in peace,” he answered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said, “May I have a word with you?”
She said, “Yes. Speak up.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “You know that the kingship was mine, and all Israel looked for me to be king. But things changed, and the kingship went to my brother instead, because the Lord gave it to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But now, I am asking you for one request. Do not turn me away.”
She said, “Tell me what it is.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Ask King Solomon (for he will not turn you down) to give me Abishag from Shunem as my wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Bathsheba said, “Very well, I will speak to the king for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Bathsheba went to King Solomon to speak to him on behalf of Adonijah. The king met her and bowed down to her. Then he sat on his throne and also set up a throne for the king’s mother, and she sat at his right hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
She said, “I am asking you for one small request. Do not turn me down.”
The king answered her, “Ask, mother, for I will not turn you down.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “Please give Abishag from Shunem to your brother Adonijah as his wife.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon answered his mother, “Why do you ask for Abishag from Shunem to be given to Adonijah? You might as well ask for the kingship for him. After all, he is my brother, my older brother! Yes, request it for him and for Abiathar the priest and for Joab son of Zeruiah!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Solomon swore by the Lord, “May God punish me severely and double it, if Adonijah does not pay with his life for this request that he has made!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, as surely as the Lord lives, who has appointed me and seated me on the throne of my father David and has established my house just as he said he would, Adonijah will die today!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Solomon gave an order to Benaiah son of Jehoiada, and he struck down Adonijah and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To Abiathar the priest the king said, “Go to your estate in Anathoth because you deserve to die. But I will not kill you today because you carried the Ark of the Lord God before my father David and because you shared in all my father’s sufferings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon drove Abiathar out from serving as priest for the Lord to fulfill the word of the Lord which had been spoken against the house of Eli in Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the news reached Joab, he fled to the Tent of the Lord and held on to the horns of the altar, for he had supported Adonijah, although he had not supported Absalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Solomon was told that Joab had fled to the Tent of the Lord and that he was there by the side of the altar, Solomon sent word to ⎣Joab, saying, “What happened to you that caused you to flee to the altar?” Joab said, “Because I was afraid of you, I fled to the Lord.” So Solomon sent word to⎦ Benaiah son of Jehoiada, “Go! Strike him down!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah went to the Tent of the Lord and called to Joab, “The king says, ‘Come out!’”
Joab answered, “No. I will die here.”
So Benaiah reported back to the king, “This is what Joab said, and this is how I responded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said to him, “Do just as he said. Strike him dead and bury him. Remove from me and from my father’s house the blood that Joab shed without cause.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord has brought the blood he shed back on his own head, because he struck down two men who were more righteous and better than he was. He killed them with the sword, but my father David did not know about it. The blood of Abner son of Ner, commander of the army of Israel, and Amasa son of Jether, commander of the army of Judah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: has come back on Joab’s head and on the heads of his descendants forever. But for David and his descendants and his house and his throne, there will be peace forever from the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Benaiah son of Jehoiada went up and struck him down and killed him. He buried him at his house in the wilderness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king put Benaiah son of Jehoiada in Joab’s place over the army. He placed Zadok the priest into Abiathar’s position.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king summoned Shimei and said to him, “Build a house for yourself in Jerusalem and live there. Do not go out of the city—ever!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the day you go out and cross the Kidron Valley, you can be sure that you will die. Your blood will be on your own head.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei said to the king, “Your decision is good. Your servant will do just as my lord the king has said.” So Shimei lived in Jerusalem for some time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of three years, two of Shimei’s slaves fled to Achish son of Ma’akah, the king of Gath. Shimei was told, “Listen! Your slaves are in Gath.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Shimei saddled his donkey and went to Achish of Gath to look for his slaves. Then he brought them back from Gath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was told that Shimei had left Jerusalem and had gone to Gath and returned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king summoned Shimei and said to him, “Did I not swear to you by the Lord and warn you that you could be sure that on the day you dared to go out of Jerusalem you would die? And didn’t you answer me, ‘Your decision is good. I have heard what you said’?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Why then did you not keep your oath to the Lord and obey the command I gave you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also said to Shimei, “In your heart you know all the evil that you did to my father David. Now the Lord has brought your evil back on your own head.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now may King Solomon be blessed, and may David’s throne be firmly established before the Lord forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king gave a command to Benaiah son of Jehoiada. He went out and struck down Shimei and killed him. In this way the kingship was firmly established in the hands of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had made a marriage alliance with Pharaoh king of Egypt. He married Pharaoh’s daughter and brought her into the City of David until he had finished building his own house, the Lord’s house, and the wall around Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people were still offering sacrifices at the high places because a house for the Name of the Lord had not yet been built in those days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon loved the Lord, so he followed the instructions of his father David, though he was still offering sacrifices and burning incense at the high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there, because it was the most important high place. Solomon offered one thousand whole burnt offerings on that altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord appeared to Solomon in Gibeon in a dream at night.
God said, “Ask for whatever you want me to give you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon said, “You have shown great mercy and faithfulness to your servant, my father David, just as he walked before you in truth, righteousness, and uprightness of heart toward you. You have shown this great mercy and faithfulness to him and have given him a son who is seated on his throne to this very day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: O Lord my God, now you have made your servant king in the place of my father David, but I am a little child. I do not know how to go out or come in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And I, your servant, am among your people whom you have chosen, a great people, who cannot be counted or numbered because they are so many.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now give to your servant a perceptive heart to judge your people, to distinguish between good and evil, for who is able to judge this great people of yours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eyes of the Lord, Solomon’s request was good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So God said to him, “Because you have asked for this, and you have not asked for a long life, nor have you asked for riches, nor have you asked for the lives of your enemies, but you have asked for discernment to reach just verdicts,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: therefore I will act according to your words. Yes, I will give you a wise and discerning heart, so that there will never have been anyone like you before you, nor will anyone like you rise up after you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, I will give you what you have not asked for: such riches and honor that there will not be anyone like you among the other kings throughout all your days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you walk in my ways by keeping my statutes and commands just as your father David did, then I will give you a long life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon woke up and realized it was a dream. So Solomon went to Jerusalem and stood before the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord. He offered whole burnt offerings and fellowship offerings, and he made a feast for all his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later, two prostitutes came and stood before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One woman said, “Hear me, my lord! This woman and I live in the same house. While she was living in the house, I gave birth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three days after I gave birth, this woman also gave birth. We were together. There was no one else in the house with us. Only the two of us were there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One night this woman’s son died because she lay on top of him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she got up in the middle of the night and took my son from beside me while I, your servant, was sleeping. She laid him next to her, and her dead son she laid next to me.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When I got up in the morning to nurse my son, there he was—dead! But when I examined him closely in the morning, I saw it was not my son, to whom I had given birth!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the other woman said, “No! The living child is really my son, and your son is the dead one!”
But the first one kept saying, “No! Your son is really the dead one, and my son is the living one!” They kept arguing like this before the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king said, “This woman says, ‘My son is the living one, and your son is the dead one.’ But this other woman says, ‘No, your son is really the dead one, and my son is the living one.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king said, “Bring me a sword.” So they brought a sword to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said, “Cut the living child in two, and give half to this woman and half to that woman.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But the woman to whom the living child belonged spoke up, because her feelings for her son were very strong. She said, “Listen to me, my lord. Give her the living child. Please don’t kill him.”
But the other woman said, “He will be neither mine nor yours. Cut him in two!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered, “Give the living child to the first woman, and do not kill him. She is his mother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel heard about the judgment which the king had rendered. They were filled with awe in his presence, because they saw that God’s wisdom was in him to administer justice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Solomon ruled over all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were his officials:
Azariah son of Zadok was the priest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Elihoreph and Ahijah, the sons of Shisha, were the secretaries.
Jehoshaphat son of Ahilud was the record keeper.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Benaiah son of Jehoiada was over the army.
Zadok and Abiathar were priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Azariah son of Nathan was supervisor over the governors.
Zabud son of Nathan, a priest, was the king’s personal advisor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahishar was the palace administrator,
and Adoniram son of Abda was in charge of forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had twelve governors, who were over all Israel. They supplied provisions for the king and for his palace. Each of them was assigned one month of the year during which he was responsible for supplying provisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
These were their names:
Ben Hur in the hill country of Ephraim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ben Deker in Makaz and in Sha’albim, Beth Shemesh, and
Elon Beth Hanan,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hesed in Arubboth (Sokoh and all the land of Hepher were his),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ben Abinadad in all the heights of Dor (Taphath daughter of
Solomon was his wife),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ba’ana son of Ahilud in Ta’anach and Megiddo, and in all Beth
Shan, which is beside Zarethan, below Jezre’el, from Beth Shan to
Abel Meholah, up to the other side of Jokmeam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ben Geber in Ramoth Gilead (the villages of Jair son of Manasseh
in Gilead belonged to him, and the region of Argob in Bashan
belonged to him, sixty great cities with walls and bronze bars),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahinadab son of Iddo in Mahanaim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ahima’az in Naphtali (he was married to Solomon’s
daughter Basemath),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’ana son of Hushai in Asher and in Be’aloth,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Paruah in Issachar,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shimei son of Ela in Benjamin,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Geber son of Uri in the land of Gilead (this included the land of both
Sihon king of the Amorites and Og king of Bashan, but there was
only one governor for that land).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah and Israel were as numerous as the sand by the sea. They were eating, drinking, and rejoicing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was ruling all the kingdoms from the River to the land of the Philistines, up to the border of Egypt. They sent tribute and workers to Solomon all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s provisions for one day were one hundred eighty bushels of fine flour and three hundred sixty bushels of plain flour,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ten stall-fed cattle, twenty pasture-fed cattle, and one hundred sheep, not to mention deer, gazelle, roebucks, and fattened poultry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Since Solomon was ruling over everything west of the River, from Tiphsah to Gaza, over all the kingdoms west of the River, he had peace on all sides.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah and Israel lived in safety, with every man sitting under his own vine and fig tree, from Dan to Beersheba, throughout Solomon’s days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had four thousand teams of horses for his chariots and twelve thousand charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His governors supplied provisions for King Solomon and for all those who gathered at King Solomon’s table. Each governor was responsible for one month, so the court lacked nothing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the barley and straw for the horses and steeds to the location assigned to each one of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God gave Solomon wisdom and very great understanding and breadth of knowledge like the sand on the seashore.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s wisdom was greater than all the wisdom of the men of the East and greater than all the wisdom of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was wiser than any man, wiser than Ethan the Ezrahite, wiser than Heman, Kalkol, or Darda, the sons of Mahol. His name was known in all the surrounding nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke three thousand proverbs, and his songs numbered one thousand and five.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke about trees, from the cedars of Lebanon to the hyssop that grows out of the wall. He also spoke about animals, birds, reptiles and other crawling things, and fish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From all the peoples and from all the kings of the earth who heard about Solomon’s wisdom, people came to listen to his wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants to Solomon because he heard that Solomon had been anointed king in his father’s place, and because Hiram had been a dear friend of David all his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sent the following message to Hiram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You know that my father David was not able to build a house for the Name of the Lord his God, because of the wars that swirled around him until the Lord put his enemies under the soles of his feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now the Lord my God has given me rest on every side. I have no adversary and face no dangerous situations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to this! I intend to build a house for the Name of the Lord my God, just as the Lord told my father, “Your son, whom I will put on your throne in your place, will build the house for my Name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now give the order to cut cedar logs for me from Lebanon. My servants will work with your servants, and I will reimburse you whatever you specify as the pay for your servants, for you know that there is no one among us who knows how to cut lumber like the Sidonians.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When Hiram heard Solomon’s words, he was very happy and he said:
Blessed be the Lord this day because he has given David a wise son to rule over this great people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Hiram sent word to Solomon:
I have heard the message you sent me. I will provide all the cedar and fir logs that you desire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My servants will bring the logs down from Lebanon to the sea, and I will put them into the sea as rafts and float them to the place that you tell me. Then we will dismantle them there, and you can transport them up from there. In exchange, you will provide all the food I desire for my palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram gave Solomon all the cedar and fir that he desired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In return, Solomon gave Hiram one hundred twenty thousand bushels of wheat as provisions for his palace and one hundred twenty thousand gallons of beaten olive oil. Solomon gave this amount to Hiram every year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord gave wisdom to Solomon just as he had promised him, so there was peace between Hiram and Solomon, and they made a treaty.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon drafted a labor force from all over Israel. It numbered thirty thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent ten thousand men per month to Lebanon in shifts. They would spend one month in Lebanon. Then for two months they would be at home. Adoniram was in charge of this forced labor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had seventy thousand men to transport materials and eighty thousand men to quarry stones in the mountains,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not counting the officials who were overseeing the work for Solomon. There were thirty-three hundred men supervising the people who were doing the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king gave a command, and they quarried large, high-quality stones to serve as a foundation for the temple building, which was made of trimmed stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s builders and Hiram’s builders and the men from Gebal cut and prepared the wood and stones to construct the temple building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the four hundred eightieth year after the people of Israel came out of the land of Egypt, during the fourth year of Solomon’s reign over Israel, in the month named Ziv, which is the second month, Solomon began to build the house for the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The house which King Solomon built for the Lord was ninety feet long, thirty feet wide, and forty-five feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The porch in front of the temple building was thirty feet wide, the same as the width of the building. It extended out fifteen feet from the front of the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made latticed windows high on the walls of the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He added a structure along the outer walls of the building, all the way around the three sides of the building. It was built against the walls of both the front room and the inner room of the sanctuary. In this structure he constructed three levels of storage rooms, all the way around the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The width of the rooms on the lowest story was seven and a half feet. The rooms of the middle story were nine feet wide, and the rooms of the third story were ten and a half feet wide, because he had built three receding ledges into the outside wall of the temple building all the way around, so that the floor beams of each story would not have to be inserted into the walls of the main building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While the building was under construction, only stones that had been finished at the quarry were used in the building. No hammer or chisel or any other iron tool was heard in the building while it was under construction.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance into the lowest story of the side rooms was on the south side of the building. Winding stairs went up to the middle floor, and also from the middle floor to the third floor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished building the house, and he covered the house with beams and planks of cedar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the floors for the storerooms that were all around the house. Each story was seven and a half feet high. Each story was supported by cedar timbers which rested on the receding ledges constructed along the walls of the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Solomon. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “In regard to this house which you are building, if you walk according to my statutes and carry out my ordinances and keep all my commands by walking according to them, you will be the one through whom I will fulfill my promise which I spoke to your father David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will dwell among the descendants of Israel, and I will not forsake my people Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon finished building the house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He paneled the inside walls of the building with cedar boards, from the floor of the building to the rafters of the ceiling. He covered the inside walls with wood. He also covered the floor of the building with boards of fir wood.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thirty feet from the back wall of the building he built a wall of cedar boards from the floor to the ceiling. He built this wall inside the building to create an inner sanctuary, the Most Holy Place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The front part of the building became a main room sixty feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gourds and open flowers were carved into the cedar on the inside of the building. Everything was covered with cedar. No stone was visible.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prepared the inner room of the sanctuary inside the building as a place to set the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The inner sanctuary was thirty feet long, thirty feet wide, and thirty feet high, and he overlaid it with pure gold.
He also overlaid the cedar altar with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon covered the inside of the building with pure gold. He stretched gold chains across the front of the inner sanctuary, and he overlaid the sanctuary with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the whole building with gold, until the whole building had been covered. He also overlaid the whole altar, which was in front of the inner sanctuary, with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the inner sanctuary he made two cherubim of olive wood. Each one was fifteen feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seven and a half feet was the length of one wing of a cherub, and seven and a half feet was the length of the other wing of a cherub. The distance from the tip of one wing to the tip of the other was fifteen feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The other cherub also was fifteen feet wide. Both of the cherubim were the same size and looked the same.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One cherub was fifteen feet tall, and so was the other cherub.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set the cherubim inside the inner sanctuary of the house. The wings of the cherubim were stretched out, so that the outer wing of the first one touched the wall, and the outer wing of the other cherub touched the opposite wall, and their wings touched one another in the middle of the room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the cherubim with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He decorated the walls on all sides of both rooms of the building with carved figures of cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He overlaid the floor of the building with gold in both the inner and outer rooms.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the entrance to the inner sanctuary, he made olive wood doors with five-sided frames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carved cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers on them and overlaid them with gold. He shaped sheets of hammered gold to cover the cherubim and the palm trees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did the same for the entrance to the front room. It had door posts of olive wood that were four-sided
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and two doors of fir wood. The door on one side was made with two folding leaves, and the door on the other side was made with two folding leaves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He carved cherubim, palm trees, and open flowers on them, and he overlaid them with gold leaf, shaped to the carvings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the inner courtyard with three courses of cut stone and one course of cedar beams.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foundation of the Lord’s house was laid in the fourth year, in the month named Ziv.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eleventh year, in the month named Bul, which is the eighth month, all the parts of the house were finished according to all its specifications. Solomon had spent seven years building it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon thirteen years to finish building his whole palace complex.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the House of the Forest of Lebanon. It was one hundred fifty feet long. It was seventy-five feet wide and forty-five feet high. It had four rows of cedar pillars, with cedar beams on top of the pillars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was roofed with cedar above the forty-five beams that rested on the pillars, fifteen beams in each row.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were three rows of windows with recessed frames on each side of the building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the doors and posts were made with square beams. They were arranged in groups of three.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built a pillared entry hall. It was seventy-five feet wide and forty-five feet deep. There was another porch in front of the pillars, and more pillars and a canopy in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made another hall, named the Hall of Justice. The throne from which he judged cases was located there. The hall was covered with cedar from floor to ceiling.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His house in which he lived was made the same way. It was on the other side of a courtyard behind the Hall of Pillars. Solomon also made another house like this hall for Pharaoh’s daughter, whom he had married.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of these were made of high-quality stone, precisely cut to the exact measure, trimmed with saws on both sides. Such stones were used from the foundation to the edge of the roof, from the outside of the complex to the great courtyard on the inside.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The foundation was made of high-quality stones, huge stones, twelve or fifteen feet long.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Above this were high-quality stones, precisely cut, with layers of cedar wood in between.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The great courtyard all the way around had three courses of cut stone and then a course of cedar beams, like the inner courtyard of the House of the Lord and the porch of that building.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon sent for Hiram from Tyre.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the son of a widow from the tribe of Naphtali, but his father was a craftsman in bronze from Tyre. Hiram too was filled with wisdom, understanding, and skill for all kinds of work in bronze. He came to King Solomon and performed the work for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cast two bronze pillars, each twenty-seven feet tall. Their circumference was eighteen feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two capitals of cast bronze to set on top of the pillars. The height of one capital was seven and a half feet, and the height of the other capital was seven and a half feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals that sat on top of the pillars were decorated with a latticework of interwoven chains. There were seven rows of decoration on one capital and seven rows on the other capital.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how he made the pillars: He made two rows of pomegranates to go above the latticework on the capitals that were on top of the pillars. He did this for each pillar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The capitals that were on top of the pillars for the porch were shaped like lilies, six feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On top of each pillar, above the bulge, beside the latticework, there were two hundred pomegranates arranged in rows all the way around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up the pillars on the porch of the temple building. He set up one pillar on the south and named it Jakin, and he set up the other pillar on the north and named it Boaz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The tops of the pillars were shaped like lilies. In this way the work for the pillars was finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the sea of cast metal. It was round, fifteen feet from rim to rim. It was seven and a half feet high. Its circumference was forty-five feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under its rim all the way around there were round, gourd-shaped ornaments, one every two inches, all the way around the sea. The ornaments were in two rows, cast as one piece with the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sea stood on twelve cattle, three facing north, three facing west, three facing south, and three facing east. The sea was set on them. All their hindquarters faced toward the center of the sea.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sea was three inches thick. Its rim was shaped like the rim of a cup, like a lily blossom. It held twelve thousand gallons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made ten bronze carts. Each cart was six feet long and six feet wide and four and a half feet tall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how the carts were constructed: They had side panels between supporting frames.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The panels between the frames were decorated with lions, cattle, and cherubim. On the frames, both above and below the lions and cattle, there were wreaths hanging down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Each cart had four bronze wheels with bronze axles, and at each of the four corners of the cart there were supports for the basin, with wreaths beside each of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The opening on top of the cart within a crowning structure was a foot and a half deep. The opening was round. It had a supporting pedestal a little more than two feet tall. Around the opening there were engravings, and the panel that surrounded the opening was square, not round.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The four wheels were underneath the side panels, and the axles for the wheels were inserted through the cart. The height of each wheel was twenty-seven inches.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wheels were made like a chariot wheel. Their axles, rims, spokes, and hubs were all of cast metal.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were supports at each of the four corners of each cart. The supports were part of the cart itself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the top of the cart there was a round opening nine inches deep. On top of the cart the supports and its panels were one piece with it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the panels between the supports he engraved cherubim, lions, and palm trees wherever there was room, with wreaths all around.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That is how he made the carts. All of them were cast with the same mold, so they had the same size and shape.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made ten bronze basins. Each basin contained two hundred forty gallons. Each basin was six feet in diameter, and there was one basin for every one of the ten carts.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He placed five carts on the south side of the temple and five on the north side of the temple. He set the sea on the south side of the temple near the southeast corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hiram made the basins, the shovels, and the sprinkling bowls.
So Hiram completed all the work that he had been assigned by King Solomon for the House of the Lord:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the two pillars, the two globe-shaped capitals on top of the pillars, the two latticeworks that covered the two globe-shaped capitals that were on top of the pillars,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the four hundred pomegranates for the two latticeworks (two rows of pomegranates for each latticework to cover the globe-shaped capitals that were on top of the pillars),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the ten carts, the ten basins on the carts,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the one sea, the twelve cattle under the sea,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the pots, the shovels, and the sprinkling bowls. All these items, which Hiram made for King Solomon for the house of the Lord, were burnished bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had them cast in clay molds in the ground, in the plain of the Jordan, between Succoth and Zarethan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon did not weigh all the vessels, because there were so many of them. The weight of the bronze was never determined.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made all the furnishings that were in the House of the Lord: the gold altar and the table for the Bread of the Presence, which was also gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The lampstands were placed in front of the inner room of the sanctuary, five on the south side, and five on the north. They also were made of pure gold, as were the flowers, the lamps, and the gold tongs,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the basins, the snuffers, the sprinkling bowls, the small dishes, and the fire pans of pure gold, and the gold hinges, both those for the doors of the inner sanctuary, that is, the Most Holy Place, and also those for the doors of the front room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In this way all the work that King Solomon did for the House of the Lord was finished. Solomon brought the things which David his father had dedicated, the silver, the gold, and the vessels, and put them in the treasuries of the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon assembled the elders of Israel, all the heads of tribes, and the leading fathers of the people of Israel to appear before him in Jerusalem, in order to bring up the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from the City of David, that is, from Zion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Israel assembled before King Solomon in the month of Ethanim, during the festival. It was the seventh month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the elders of Israel came, and the priests lifted up the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought up the Ark of the Lord, the Tent of Meeting, and all the holy vessels which were in the tent. The priests and the Levites brought them up.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon, along with the whole congregation of Israel who had gathered with him in front of the ark, was sacrificing sheep and cattle, too many to be counted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests brought the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord to its place in the inner sanctuary of the house, to the Most Holy Place, under the wings of the cherubim,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for the cherubim were spreading their wings over the place for the ark, so that the cherubim covered the ark and its poles with their wings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles were so long that the ends of the poles could be seen from the Holy Place in front of the inner sanctuary, but they could not be seen from outside. They are there to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except the two stone tablets, which Moses had placed there at Horeb, where the Lord made a covenant with the people of Israel when they came out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the priests came out from the Holy Place, the cloud filled the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests were not able to take their positions to minister in the presence of the cloud, because the Glory of the Lord had filled the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “The Lord has said that he dwells in thick darkness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have truly built a majestic house for you, a place for you to dwell forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned and blessed the whole congregation of Israel, while the whole congregation of Israel was standing there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Solomon said:
Blessed is the Lord, the God of Israel. What he said with his mouth to my father David, he has fulfilled with his hand.
The Lord said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “From the day I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I did not choose a city from all the tribes of Israel in which to build a house for my Name to be there, ⎣nor did I choose any man to be a leader over my people Israel; but now I have chosen Jerusalem for my Name to be there,⎦ and I have chosen David to be over my people Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It was on my father David’s heart to build a house for the Name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, the Lord said to my father David, “It was on your heart to build a house for my Name. That was a good thing to desire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you will not build the house. Your son, who will come from your own body, will build the house for my Name.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord kept his word which he had spoken, and I arose in the place of my father David. I am seated on the throne of Israel, just as the Lord said. I have built this house for the Name of the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I have established a place there for the Ark, which contains the covenant of the Lord, which he made with our fathers when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon stood in front of the altar in the presence of the whole congregation of Israel and spread out his hands toward heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said:
O Lord, God of Israel, there is no God like you in the heavens above or on the earth below. You keep the covenant of mercy and faithfulness with your servants who walk before you with all their heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have kept the word which you spoke to your servant, my father David. What you have said with your mouth you have fulfilled with your hand, as it is today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Lord God of Israel, guard for your servant, my father David, the promise you made to him when you said, “You will never fail to have a man sitting on the throne of Israel in my presence, if your sons guard their ways by walking in my law just as you have walked before me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, O God of Israel, let the words which you spoke to your servant, my father David, be confirmed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But will God really dwell on the earth? In truth, the heavens, even the highest heaven, cannot contain you. How much less this house, which I have built!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But turn your face toward the prayer of your servant and toward his plea for mercy. O Lord my God, listen to the cry and the prayer which your servant offers before you today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your eyes be open toward this house night and day, toward this place where you said, “My Name will be there,” to hear the prayer which your servant offers toward this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you hear the plea for mercy of your servant and of your people Israel, which they pray toward this place, then hear in your dwelling place in heaven—hear and forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When a man sins against his neighbor, and his neighbor places him under an oath, and the oath is presented before your altar in this house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and take action. Provide justice for your servants by declaring the wicked person guilty and bringing his ways down on his own head, and by declaring the righteous person innocent and dealing with him according to his righteousness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your people Israel are defeated by their enemies because they sinned against you, and when they return to you and praise your Name and pray and seek your favor in this house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear in heaven and forgive the sin of your people Israel and bring them back to the land which you gave to their fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the heavens are shut up, and there is no rain because they sinned against you, and when they pray toward this place, and they praise your Name and turn from their sin because you have humbled them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear from heaven and forgive the sin of your servants, your people Israel. Yes, teach them the good way in which they are to walk, and provide rain for the land which you gave to your people as an inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When there is famine in the land, when there is plague, when there is blight or mildew or locusts or grasshoppers, when their enemies are in the land besieging their gates, in every disease, in every sickness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: hear every prayer and every plea for mercy which any individual presents or which your whole people Israel presents. When each one knows the affliction of his own heart, when he spreads out his hands toward this house,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: hear in heaven, your dwelling place, and forgive. Then act and give to each person according to all his ways, because you know his heart (yes, you alone know the heart of every human being),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that they may fear you all the days they live on the soil which you gave to our fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also for the foreigner, who is not one of your people Israel, but who comes from a distant land because of your Name
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (for they will hear about your great Name, your mighty hand, and your outstretched arm, and they will come and pray toward this house),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: for that foreigner, hear in heaven, which is your dwelling place, and do everything for which that foreigner cries out to you, so that all the peoples of the earth may know your Name and fear you, just as your people Israel do, and because they know that your Name is proclaimed in this house which I have built.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When your people go out for battle against their enemy on whatever way you send them, and when they pray to the Lord facing toward the city which you have chosen and toward the house which I have built for your Name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then from heaven hear their prayer and their plea for mercy, and provide justice for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they sin against you (for there is no one who does not sin) and you become angry with them, and you give them up to their enemies, and their captors exile them to an enemy land, whether distant or near,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when they are in the land where they were exiled and they turn their hearts back, and they repent and pray to you in the land of their exile and say, “We have sinned and become guilty and done evil,”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: when they return to you with all their heart and with all their soul in the land of their enemies where they were exiled, and they pray in the direction of their land, which you gave to their fathers, toward the city which you chose and toward the house which I have built for your Name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then hear their prayers and their plea for mercy from heaven, your dwelling place, and provide justice for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pardon your people who have sinned against you and all their rebellious deeds that they have committed against you. Have compassion by causing their enemies to show them compassion.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For they are your people and your possession, which you brought out of Egypt, from the midst of the iron-smelting furnace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Let your eyes be open to the plea for mercy from your servant and to the plea for mercy from your people Israel. Hear them whenever they cry out to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For you singled them out for yourself as your possession from all the peoples of the earth, just as you said through Moses your servant when you brought our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished offering all these prayers and pleas for mercy to the Lord, he got up from the altar of the Lord, where he had been kneeling with his hands spread out toward heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he stood and blessed the whole congregation of Israel with a loud voice:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Blessed be the Lord, who has given rest to his people Israel, just as he said he would. Not one word has failed from all his good words which he spoke through Moses his servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord our God be with us, just as he was with our fathers. May he never leave us or abandon us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May he turn our hearts to him, to walk in all his ways and to listen to his commands, regulations, and ordinances, which he commanded to our fathers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May these words which I have prayed before the Lord be near the Lord our God day and night so that he provides justice for his servant and for his people Israel forever,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: so that all the peoples of the earth may know that the Lord is God. There is no other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May your hearts be fully committed to the Lord our God, in order to walk in his regulations and to keep his commands, just as is the case today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all Israel with him offered sacrifices before the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sacrificed fellowship offerings to the Lord: twenty-two thousand cattle and one hundred twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the people of Israel dedicated the House of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day the king consecrated the center of the courtyard which was in front of the House of the Lord, so that he could offer whole burnt offerings and grain offerings and the fat of the fellowship offerings there, because the bronze altar which was before the Lord was too small to hold the whole burnt offerings and grain offerings and the fat of the fellowship offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Solomon kept the festival, and all Israel kept the festival with him. They were a great congregation that had come from throughout the land, from Lebo Hamath to the Stream of Egypt before the Lord our God. ⎣⎦ The festival lasted seven days, and then seven days more, fourteen days in all.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day he sent them home, and they blessed the king. Then they went home, and their hearts were glad because of all the good which the Lord had done for his servant David and for his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon had finished building the house for the Lord and the house for the king, and he had done all that he desired,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the Lord appeared to Solomon a second time, just as he had appeared to him in Gibeon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The Lord said to him:
I have heard your prayer and the plea for mercy that you offered before me. I have consecrated this house, which you built, by putting my Name there forever. My eyes and my heart will be there for all time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for you, if you walk before me in purity of heart and with integrity as your father David did, so that you carry out everything that I command you, and you keep all my statutes and my ordinances,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will maintain your royal throne over Israel forever, just as I said to your father David, “You will not fail to have a man upon the throne of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But if any of you or your sons turn away from me and do not keep my commands and statutes, which I set before you, but you serve other gods and bow down to them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: then I will cut off Israel from the face of the ground which I gave them. I will take my presence away from the house which I consecrated for my Name. Israel will become proverbial as an object of ridicule for all peoples.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Though this house is now exalted, all who pass by it will be appalled and will hiss and say, “Why did the Lord do this to this land and to this house?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They will reply, “Because they abandoned the Lord their God, who brought their fathers out of the land of Egypt, and they embraced other gods and worshipped and served them. That is why the Lord brought all this evil on them.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of twenty years, when Solomon had completed these two buildings, the house of the Lord and the house of the king,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave Hiram twenty towns in the land of Galilee, because Hiram king of Tyre had been supplying Solomon with cedar and fir wood and with as much gold as he desired.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hiram left Tyre to see the towns which Solomon had given him, but he was not pleased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “What kind of towns are these towns which you have given me, my brother?” He called them the Land of Kabul, a name they have to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hiram had sent the king one hundred twenty talents of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is the account of the forced labor, which King Solomon raised to build the house for the Lord, his own house, the Millo, and the walls of Jerusalem, as well as Hazor, Megiddo, and Gezer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Pharaoh king of Egypt had come up and captured Gezer. He burned it and killed the Canaanites who were living in the city. Then he gave it as a wedding present to his daughter, Solomon’s wife.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon built Gezer, lower Beth Horon,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Baalath, Tadmor in the wilderness,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all of Solomon’s towns for storehouses, the towns for his chariots, the towns for charioteers, and everything Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, in Lebanon, and in all the land he ruled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people who remained from the Amorites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Hivites, and the Jebusites, who were not part of the people of Israel—
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: their descendants who remained in the land, whom the Israelites were not able to destroy completely—were drafted for forced labor by Solomon. They are serving right up to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Solomon did not press the people of Israel into service. Rather, they were his warriors, his government officials, his staff, his military officers, the commanders of his chariots, and his charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the officials who were overseeing Solomon’s work. Five hundred fifty officials were overseeing the people doing the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Pharaoh’s daughter moved up from the City of David to the house Solomon built for her. Then he built the Millo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three times a year Solomon offered whole burnt offerings and fellowship offerings on the altar which he had built before the Lord, and he burned incense before the Lord. In this way he completed the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon built a fleet at Ezion Geber, which is near Elat on the shore of the Red Sea in the land of Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, along with that fleet, Hiram sent his servants, men who worked on ships and who knew the sea, to serve with the servants of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went to Ophir, and they obtained four hundred twenty talents of gold there and brought it to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Queen of Sheba heard about Solomon’s fame, which was connected with the fame of the Lord, so she came to test him with hard questions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She came to Jerusalem with a very great entourage—with camels carrying spices and a large quantity of gold and precious stones. She came to Solomon and told him everything that was on her heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions. There was nothing hidden from the king that he could not explain to her.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Queen of Sheba saw all the wisdom of Solomon, the house which he built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the food on his table. When she saw the council meeting of his officials, the careful attention of his ministers, as well as their attire, his cupbearers, and the whole burnt offerings which he offered at the House of the Lord, it took her breath away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said to the king, “The report I heard in my own country about your accomplishments and your wisdom is true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I did not believe the report until I came and saw it with my own eyes. The truth is, not even half of it was told to me! Your wisdom and wealth surpass the report which I heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Blessed are your men, blessed are your servants, who stand before you continually hearing your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May the Lord your God be blessed, who was pleased to put you on the throne of Israel. Because the Lord loves Israel forever, he made you king to administer justice and righteousness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she gave the king one hundred twenty talents of gold and a great quantity of spices and many precious stones. There was never again anything comparable to the huge amount of spices and incense which the Queen of Sheba gave to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, Hiram’s fleet brought gold from Ophir and a great quantity of almug wood and also precious stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made the almug wood into steps for the Lord’s house and for the house of the king, as well as lyres and harps for his singers. So much fine almug wood has never been brought or seen to this present day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave to the Queen of Sheba all she desired, whatever she asked for, besides what he had given to her from his royal resources. Then she and her servants returned to her country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The weight of gold which came to Solomon in one year was six hundred sixty-six talents,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not counting what he collected from merchants and traders and from all the Arabian kings and the governors of the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made two hundred large shields of hammered gold. He put seven and a half pounds of gold into each large shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made three hundred small shields of hammered gold. He put almost four pounds of gold into each small shield. The king put them in the House of the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made a large ivory throne and overlaid it with fine gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were six steps to the throne. The throne had a rounded back and armrests on either side of the seat. Two lions were standing beside the armrests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Twelve lions were standing on the steps, one on each end of each step. Nothing like it had ever been made for any kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Solomon’s drinking vessels were gold, and all of the utensils in the House of the Forest of Lebanon were pure gold. No silver was used, because it was considered of little value in Solomon’s days,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because Solomon’s merchant fleet was at sea with Hiram’s fleet, and once every three years the fleet returned, carrying gold and silver, ivory, monkeys, and peacocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon was greater than all the kings of the earth in wealth and wisdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole world sought an audience with Solomon to hear the wisdom which God put in his heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They each brought gifts: articles of gold and silver, clothing, scents, spices, horses and mules, year after year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon accumulated chariots and charioteers until he had fourteen hundred chariots and twelve thousand charioteers. He stationed them in the chariot cities and with the king in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as plentiful as stone in Jerusalem and cedar wood as abundant as sycamore trees in the Shephelah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and from Kue. The king’s dealers bought them from Kue for the market price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A chariot could be imported from Egypt for six hundred silver shekels and a horse for one hundred fifty. In this same way they were exported to all the kings of the Hittites and the kings of Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon, however, loved many foreign women besides Pharaoh’s daughter, including Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Sidonians, and Hittites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came from the nations about which the Lord had said to the people of Israel, “You must not enter into marriage with them, and they must not enter into marriage with you, or they will turn your hearts after other gods.” Solomon clung to them in love.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had seven hundred wives who held the rank of princess and three hundred concubines. So they turned his heart away.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon became old, his wives turned his heart after other gods, so that his heart was not fully devoted to the Lord as the heart of his father David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon followed Ashtarte, the goddess of the Sidonians, and Milcom, the detestable god of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Solomon did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He did not devote himself to the Lord as his father David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon built a high place for Chemosh, the detestable god of Moab, on the hill east of Jerusalem and for Molek, the detestable god of the Ammonites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did the same for all his foreign wives, who were burning incense and making sacrifices to their gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord was angry with Solomon because his heart had turned away from the Lord, the God of Israel, who had appeared to him twice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had given him the command not to follow other gods, but Solomon did not keep the Lord’s command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Lord said to Solomon, “Because this is your attitude, and because you did not keep my covenant and my statutes which I commanded you, I will surely rip the kingdom out of your hands and give it to your servant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I will not do it during your lifetime because of your father David. I will rip it from your son’s hand.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will not rip away the whole kingdom. One tribe I will give to your son for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, which I have chosen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord raised up Hadad the Edomite, from the royal line of Edom, as an adversary for Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Earlier, while David was at war with Edom, when Joab the commander of the army went up to bury the dead, he struck down every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For six months Joab and all Israel stayed there until he exterminated every male in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But while Hadad was a young boy, he had fled with some Edomites from among his father’s servants to go to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they set out from Midian and went to Paran. They took some men with them from Paran and went to Egypt, to Pharaoh king of Egypt. He gave Hadad a house and decreed an allowance of food for him and gave him land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hadad found great favor in the eyes of Pharaoh, so Pharaoh gave him the sister of his own wife, the sister of Queen Tahpenes, as his wife.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The sister of Tahpenes bore him a son named Genubath. Tahpenes weaned him in the house of Pharaoh, so Genubath was in the house of Pharaoh with Pharaoh’s own sons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later Hadad heard that David rested with his fathers and that Joab the commander of the army was dead. So Hadad said to Pharaoh, “Send me back to my own country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Pharaoh said to him, “What are you lacking here with me, so that you want to go back to your own country?”
He said, “Nothing, but please let me go.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: God also raised up another adversary for Solomon, Rezon son of Eliada, who had fled from his master, Hadadezer king of Zobah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After David had destroyed Zobah’s army, Rezon gathered men around himself and was the commander of a band of raiders. They went to Damascus and lived there and ruled Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was Israel’s adversary during all the days of Solomon, in addition to all the difficulties which Hadad caused. He was hostile to Israel, and he ruled over Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam son of Nebat was an Ephraimite from Zeredah. His mother’s name was Zeruah. She was a widow. Jeroboam was Solomon’s official, but he rebelled against the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is the account of how he rebelled against the king.
When Solomon was rebuilding the Millo and repairing the gap in the wall in the city of his father David,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam showed that he was a very capable man. When Solomon saw that the young man was a capable worker, he appointed him over all the forced labor of the house of Joseph.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, when Jeroboam left Jerusalem, the prophet Ahijah from Shiloh met him on the road. Ahijah was wearing a new cloak. The two of them were alone in the field.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahijah took the new cloak he was wearing and tore it into twelve pieces.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He told Jeroboam, “Take ten pieces for yourself, because this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says.”
Look, I am tearing the kingdom out of Solomon’s hand, and I will give you ten tribes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But one tribe will remain with him for the sake of my servant David and for the sake of Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen from all the tribes of Israel.
