verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is because they have abandoned me and worshipped Ashtarte the goddess of the Sidonians, and Chemosh the god of Moab, and Milcom the god of the Ammonites. They have not walked in my ways by doing what is upright in my eyes and keeping my commands and judgments as his father David did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will not take the whole kingdom from his hand because I appointed him leader for all the days of his life for the sake of my servant David, whom I chose and who kept my commands and statutes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, I will take the kingdom from his son’s hand, and I will give ten tribes to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: To his son I will give one tribe in order that there may be a lamp for my servant David before me in Jerusalem, the city where I chose to put my Name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I will take you, and you will be king over all that your soul desires. You will be king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you listen to all that I command you, and if you walk in my ways and do what is right in my eyes, keeping my decrees and my statutes, just as my servant David did, then I will be with you, and I will build an enduring house for you, just as I built for David. I will give Israel to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I will humble the seed of David because of this, but not forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As a result Solomon tried to kill Jeroboam, but Jeroboam fled to Shishak king of Egypt. He stayed in Egypt until Solomon died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Solomon’s acts, everything he did, and his wisdom, are they not written in the Book of the Acts of Solomon?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon was king over all Israel in Jerusalem for forty years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon rested with his fathers and was buried in the City of David, his father. His son Rehoboam ruled as king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem, because all Israel had gone there to make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jeroboam son of Nebat was still in Egypt where he had fled from King Solomon, he heard about this, and he returned from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the people sent for him.
Then Jeroboam and the entire assembly of Israel came and said to Rehoboam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father made our yoke heavy. Now lighten your father’s harsh service and the heavy yoke he laid on us, and we will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam said to them, “Leave me for three days and then return to me.” So the people left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam consulted the elders who had served his father Solomon while he was alive. He asked, “What answer do you advise me to give to these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to him, “If today you become a servant to this people—if you serve them and answer them with kind words—then they will be your servants for all time.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he rejected the advice which the old men offered him. Instead, he consulted the young men who had grown up with him and were serving him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “What answer do you advise that we should give to these people who said to me, ‘Lighten the yoke that your father laid on us’?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young men who had grown up with him said, “This is what you should say to this people who said to you, ‘Your father laid a heavy yoke on us. Now lighten our yoke.’ Tell them this: ‘My little finger is thicker than my father’s waist.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: My father imposed a heavy yoke on you. I will make your yoke heavier. My father punished you with whips, but I will punish you with scorpions.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam on the third day, because the king had said, “Come back to me on the third day.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered the people harshly, because he had rejected the advice which the old men had offered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke to them as the young men advised him: “My father made your yoke heavy, and I will add to your yoke. My father punished you with whips, but I will punish you with scorpions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king did not listen to the people, because this turn of events was from the Lord, in order to fulfill his word, which the Lord had spoken to Jeroboam son of Nebat through Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
All Israel saw that the king had not listened to them. So the people answered the king:
What share do we have in David?
No portion in the son of Jesse!
To your tents, Israel!
Now look after your own house, David!
So Israel went to their tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam continued to rule over the people of Israel who were living in the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sent out Adoram, who was in charge of forced labor, but all Israel stoned him to death. King Rehoboam, however, was able to get in his chariot to flee to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Israel has been in rebellion against the house of David until this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all Israel heard that Jeroboam had returned, they summoned him to the assembly and made him king over all Israel. No tribe was left which followed the house of David, except the tribe of Judah alone.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam returned to Jerusalem, he assembled the whole house of Judah and the tribe of Benjamin, one hundred eighty thousand specially chosen soldiers, to fight against the house of Israel and to restore the kingdom to Rehoboam, the son of Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the word of God came to Shemaiah, the man of God:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Say the following to Rehoboam son of Solomon, king of Judah, and to all the house of Judah and Benjamin and to the rest of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
This is what the Lord says. Do not attack and do not fight against your brothers, the people of Israel. Go home, every one of you, for this turn of events is from me.”
So they listened to the word of the Lord, and they returned home, just as the Lord said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeroboam fortified Shechem in the hill country of Ephraim, and he lived there. From there he also went out and fortified Penuel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeroboam said in his heart, “Now the kingship will go back to the house of David.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If this people goes up to offer sacrifices at the House of the Lord in Jerusalem, then the hearts of the people will return to their master, Rehoboam king of Judah. Then they will kill me and return to Rehoboam king of Judah.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After the king sought advice, he made two golden calves and said to the people, “Going up to Jerusalem is too much trouble for you. Here are your gods, Israel, who brought you up from the land of Egypt!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up one in Bethel and the other one in Dan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This sin took hold, and the people traveled as far as Dan to worship.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam also made shrines on the high places, and he appointed priests from all kinds of people, even though they were not Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam instituted a festival in the eighth month, on the fifteenth day of the month, like the festival that is held in Judah. He offered sacrifices on the altar. He did this in Bethel, sacrificing to the calves he had made. He appointed priests in Bethel for the high places he had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He instituted sacrifices on the altar which he had made in Bethel, on the fifteenth day of the eighth month, a month which he chose on his own. He instituted a festival for the people of Israel. He went up to the altar to send offerings up in smoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that moment, by the word of the Lord, a man of God came from Judah to Bethel while Jeroboam was standing in front of the altar to send offerings up in smoke.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cried out against the altar by the word of Lord, “Altar! Altar! This is what the Lord says. Listen! A son will be born to the house of David. Josiah will be his name. On you he will slaughter the priests of the high places, who are burning offerings on you, and human bones will be burned on you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day he gave them a sign: “This is the sign which the Lord announces: This very altar will be torn apart, and the ashes on it will be poured out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When King Jeroboam heard this message that the man of God had proclaimed against the altar at Bethel, he pointed at him from the altar and cried, “Seize him!” But the hand that the king pointed at the man withered, and he could not pull it back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the altar was torn apart, and the ashes poured out from the altar in fulfillment of the sign which the man of God had given by the word of the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king responded to the man of God, “Intercede before the Lord your God and pray on my behalf that my hand may be restored for me.” So the man of God interceded before the Lord, and the king’s hand was restored for him, so that it was like it had been before.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to the man of God, “Come to the palace with me and eat something, and I will give you a gift.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the man of God said to the king, “Even if you gave me half your wealth, I would not go with you, and I would not eat bread or drink water in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what I was commanded by the word of the Lord: Do not eat bread and do not drink water, and do not return by the way you came.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he left by a different road. He did not go back the same way he had come to Bethel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another prophet, an old man, was living in Bethel. His sons came and told him everything that the man of God had done that day in Bethel. They also reported to their father the words he had spoken to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then their father said to them, “Which road did he take?” So his sons showed him the road which the man of God from Judah had taken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told his sons, “Saddle my donkey.” So they saddled his donkey, and he got on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He went after the man of God and found him sitting under a terebinth tree.
He said to him, “Are you the man of God who came from Judah?”
He answered, “I am.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet said to him, “Come with me to my house and have something to eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he said, “No, I cannot return with you, or go with you, or eat bread and drink water with you in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For I was told by the word of the Lord, ‘Do not eat bread and do not drink water there, and do not return by the same road you came on.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the old prophet said to him, “I also am a prophet, just like you, and an angel told me by the word of the Lord, ‘Bring him back with you to your house so that he may eat bread and drink water.’” But he was lying to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man of God returned with him and ate bread in his house and drank water.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While they were sitting at the table, the word of the Lord came to the prophet who had brought the man of God back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He cried out to the man of God who had come from Judah, saying, “This is what the Lord says. Because you have rebelled against the mouth of the Lord and have not obeyed the command which the Lord your God gave you,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but instead you came back and ate bread and drank water in the place about which he had told you, ‘Do not eat bread or drink water there,’ your corpse will not enter the tomb of your fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then after he ate and drank, the old prophet saddled the donkey for the prophet whom he had brought back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the man of God went on his way, a lion attacked him and killed him. His corpse was left lying on the road, and his donkey remained standing next to it. The lion was also standing next to the corpse.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then some men who were passing by saw the corpse lying on the road, and the lion was standing next to the corpse. They came and told the story in the city where the old prophet lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the prophet who had brought the man of God back from his journey heard this, he said, “This is the man of God who rebelled against the mouth of the Lord. Now the Lord has given him to the lion. It mauled him and killed him according to the word of the Lord, which he spoke to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to his sons, “Saddle my donkey.” So they saddled it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he went and found the corpse of the man of God lying on the road, with the donkey and the lion standing beside the corpse. The lion had not eaten the corpse nor had it mauled the donkey.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The old prophet picked up the corpse of the man of God, placed it on the donkey, and brought it back to his own city to mourn and to bury it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He laid the corpse in his own tomb, and they mourned over him, “Oh, my brother!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had buried him, the old prophet said to his sons, “When I die and you bury me, lay my bones to rest beside the bones of the man of God, in the same tomb where he is buried.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the message which he proclaimed by the word of the Lord against the altar in Bethel and against all the shrines of the high places in the cities of Samaria will certainly come true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Even after this, Jeroboam did not turn from his evil way, but he continued to appoint all kinds of people as priests for the high places. He ordained anyone who wanted to be a priest for the high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This was the sin of the house of Jeroboam, which erased and exterminated it from the face of the earth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time, Jeroboam’s son Abijah became very sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam told his wife, “Go and disguise yourself so that you will not be recognized as Jeroboam’s wife. Then go to Shiloh. That is where the prophet Ahijah is. He is the one who told me that I would become king over this people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Take with you ten loaves of bread, some baked goods, and a jar of honey, and go to him. He will tell you what will happen to the boy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam’s wife did as she was told. She went to Shiloh and came to Ahijah’s house. Now Ahijah was no longer able to see due to old age. His eyes stared straight ahead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord had told Ahijah, “Be ready! Jeroboam’s wife is coming to inquire from you about her son because he is seriously ill. When she comes, you will say this and this to her. But when she comes, she will be disguised.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahijah heard her footsteps as she came to the door, he said, “Come in, wife of Jeroboam! Why are you disguised? I am a messenger with bad news for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Go and tell Jeroboam that this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says.”
I raised you up from among the people, and I appointed you leader over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I tore the kingdom from the house of David and gave it to you. But you have not been like my servant David, who kept my commands and followed me with all his heart by doing only what was right in my eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You have done more evil than all those who came before you, and you have made for yourself other gods and images of cast metal, provoking me to anger. You threw me behind your back.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Therefore, listen to this! I myself will bring disaster on the house of Jeroboam. I will exterminate everyone in Israel connected to Jeroboam, all those who urinate against the wall, both bound and free. I will burn up the house of Jeroboam as completely as manure is burned.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dogs will eat those who belong to Jeroboam who die in the city, and the birds of the air will eat those who die in the country, because the Lord has spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for you, go home. As soon as your feet enter the city, the boy will die.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All Israel will mourn for him, and they will bury him. Indeed, from those who belong to Jeroboam he alone will be buried in a tomb, because in the house of Jeroboam some good is found in him before the Lord, the God of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord will raise up for himself a king over Israel who will cut off the house of Jeroboam. This is the day. Indeed, it begins right now.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord will strike Israel until it sways like a reed swaying in the water. He will uproot Israel from this good land, which he gave to their fathers, and he will scatter them beyond the River, because they made their Asherah poles, provoking the Lord to anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yes, he will give Israel up because of the sins which Jeroboam himself committed and which he caused Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam’s wife got up, set out, and traveled to Tirzah. When she crossed the threshold of the house, the boy died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried him, and all Israel mourned for him according to the word of the Lord, which he spoke through his servant, the prophet Ahijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Jeroboam’s acts, the wars he fought and the way he ruled, you can find them written in the annals of the kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam was king for twenty-two years. He rested with his fathers. Then his son Nadab became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, Rehoboam son of Solomon was king in Judah. He was forty-one years old when he became king, and he ruled for seventeen years in Jerusalem, the city the Lord had chosen from all the tribes of Israel to put his Name there. The name of Rehoboam’s mother was Na’amah the Ammonite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Judah did evil in the eyes of the Lord, and they provoked him to anger more than all their fathers had done with the sins that they committed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They built for themselves high places, sacred memorial stones, and Asherah poles on every high hill and under every leafy tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were even male cult prostitutes in the land. They practiced all the abominations of the nations which the Lord had driven out before the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fifth year of King Rehoboam, Shishak king of Egypt attacked Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the treasures of the house of the Lord and the treasures of the king’s palace. He took everything, including all the gold shields that Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them, and he entrusted them to the captains of the guard who were keeping watch at the entrance of the king’s palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king went to the House of the Lord, the guards would carry the shields. Then the guards would return them to the armory.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Rehoboam’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all their days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam rested with his fathers, and he was buried with his fathers in the City of David. The name of his mother was Na’amah the Ammonite. Then his son Abijam became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam son of Nebat, Abijam became king over Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Ma’akah, granddaughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He walked in all the sins which his father had practiced before him, and his heart was not fully devoted to the Lord as the heart of his grandfather David had been.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But for the sake of David, the Lord his God gave him a lamp in Jerusalem by raising up his son after him and by making Jerusalem strong.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this because David had done what was right in the eyes of the Lord, and he did not turn from all that the Lord commanded all the days of his life, except in the matter of Uriah the Hittite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam all the days of his life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Abijam’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah? There was war between Abijam and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijam rested with his fathers, and they buried him in the City of David. Then his son Asa became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twentieth year of Jeroboam king of Israel, Asa king of Judah became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled for forty-one years in Jerusalem. His grandmother’s name was Ma’akah granddaughter of Abishalom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what was right in the eyes of the Lord as his father David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He drove the male shrine prostitutes out of the land, and he removed all the filthy idols which his fathers had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In addition, he also removed his grandmother Ma’akah from being queen mother because she had made an obscene image of Asherah. Asa cut down her obscene image and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the high places were not removed. Nevertheless, Asa’s heart was fully committed to the Lord all his days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought silver and gold and vessels and utensils into the House of the Lord as dedicated offerings for himself and his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Asa and Ba’asha king of Israel throughout all their days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’asha king of Israel attacked Judah, and he fortified Ramah in order to prevent anyone from going out or coming in to Asa king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Asa took all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of the House of the Lord and the treasuries of the king’s palace, and he gave them to his officials. Then King Asa sent them to Ben Hadad son of Tabrimmon, the son of Hezion king of Aram, who was living in Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “There should be a treaty between you and me as there was between my father and your father. Look, I am sending you a gift of silver and gold. Come, break your treaty with Ba’asha king of Israel, so that he will withdraw from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hadad listened to King Asa and sent the commanders of his army against the cities of Israel. They attacked Ijon, Dan, Abel Beth Ma’akah, and all of Kinneret, as well as all the land of Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ba’asha heard about this, he stopped fortifying Ramah, and he stayed in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa summoned all Judah—no one was exempt—and they carried away the stones of Ramah and the timber with which Ba’asha had been building, and King Asa used them to fortify Geba in Benjamin and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for all the rest of Asa’s acts and all his mighty deeds and everything else he did and the cities he built, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah? But in his old age his feet became diseased.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa rested with his fathers, and they buried him in the City of David. Then his son Jehoshaphat became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nadab son of Jeroboam became king over Israel in the second year of Asa king of Judah. He ruled over Israel for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He walked in the ways of his father and in the sin which he had caused Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’asha son of Ahijah from the house of Issachar conspired against him and struck him down in Gibbethon, which belongs to the Philistines. (Nadab and all Israel were laying siege to Gibbethon.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’asha killed him in the third year of Asa king of Judah and became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ba’asha became king, he struck down the whole house of Jeroboam, until it was exterminated according to the word of the Lord, which he had spoken through his servant Ahijah from Shiloh. For Jeroboam’s house he did not spare anyone who breathed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the sins which Jeroboam committed and which he caused Israel to commit when he provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Nadab’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was war between Asa and Ba’asha king of Israel all their days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year of Asa king of Judah, Ba’asha son of Ahijah became king over all Israel in Tirzah and reigned for twenty-four years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord by walking in the way of Jeroboam and in the sins that Jeroboam had caused Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then this word of the Lord came to Jehu son of Hanani against Ba’asha:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “I raised you up from the dust and appointed you leader over my people Israel, but you have walked in the ways of Jeroboam, and you have caused my people Israel to sin, provoking me to anger with their sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Look! I am about to burn up Ba’asha and his house. I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dogs will eat those who belong to Ba’asha who die in the city, and the birds of the air will eat those who die in the country.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Ba’asha’s acts and everything he did and his mighty deeds, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ba’asha rested with his fathers, and he was buried in Tirzah. Then his son Elah became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The word of the Lord had come against Ba’asha and his house through the prophet Jehu son of Hanani, because of all the evil which he had done in the eyes of the Lord, provoking him to anger with the work of his hands by becoming like the house of Jeroboam, and also because he had struck down Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twenty-sixth year of Asa king of Judah, Elah son of Ba’asha became king over Israel in Tirzah for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But his officer Zimri, the commander of half his chariots, conspired against him while Elah was in Tirzah getting drunk at the house of Arza, the palace administrator of Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zimri came in and struck him down and killed him in the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, and he became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zimri became king, as soon as he was seated on the throne, he struck down the entire house of Ba’asha. He did not leave for him anyone who urinates against the wall, neither relatives nor friends.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Zimri exterminated the entire house of Ba’asha according to the word of the Lord, which he spoke to Ba’asha through the prophet Jehu.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did this because of all the sins which Ba’asha and his son Elah committed and which they caused Israel to commit. They provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with their useless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Elah’s acts and everything he did, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the twenty-seventh year of Asa king of Judah, Zimri reigned as king in Tirzah for seven days. The army was laying siege to Gibbethon, which belonged to the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The army which was laying siege heard the report that Zimri had conspired against the king and had already struck him down. So in the camp on that day all Israel made Omri, the commander of the army, king over Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Omri and all Israel went up from Gibbethon and laid siege to Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Zimri saw that the city had fallen, he went into the fortified part of the palace, and he burned it down on himself. So he died
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: because of the sin he committed by doing evil in the eyes of the Lord by walking in the ways of Jeroboam and in the sin which he had caused Israel to commit.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Zimri’s acts and the conspiracy he led, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of Israel were divided. Half of the people supported making Tibni son of Ginath king. Half supported Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the people who were for Omri were stronger than the people who were for Tibni son of Ginath, so Tibni died, and Omri became king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-first year of Asa king of Judah, Omri became king over Israel for twelve years. He ruled for six years in Tirzah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he bought the hill of Samaria from Shemer for two talents of silver. He built up the hill, and he named the city he built after Shemer, the owner of the hill of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri did evil in the eyes of the Lord. He committed more evil than all those who had gone before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He walked in all the ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat and in the sin which he caused Israel to commit, provoking the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger with his useless idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Omri’s acts, the things he did, and the mighty deeds he accomplished, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Omri rested with his fathers, and he was buried in Samaria. Then his son Ahab became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab son of Omri became king over Israel in the thirty-eighth year of Asa king of Judah. Ahab son of Omri ruled over Israel in Samaria for twenty-two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab son of Omri committed more evil in the eyes of the Lord than all those who had gone before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He considered it a trivial thing to walk in the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat. He married Jezebel daughter of Ethbaal, king of the Sidonians. He served Baal and bowed down to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He erected an altar to Baal in the house of Baal which he built in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab made an Asherah pole and did even more to provoke the Lord God of Israel than all the kings of Israel who had gone before him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the days of Ahab, Hiel of Bethel built Jericho. At the cost of his firstborn son Abiram, he laid its foundations, and at the cost of his youngest son Segub, he set up its gates. This fulfilled the word of the Lord which he had spoken through Joshua son of Nun.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah from Tishbe, one of the settlers in Gilead, said to Ahab, “As surely as the Lord lives, the God of Israel before whom I stand, there will be no dew or rain during the coming years, except at my word.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Leave this place and turn east. Hide yourself by the Kerith Ravine, east of the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will drink from the stream, and I will command the ravens to provide for you there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elijah went and did just as the Lord had said. He lived in the Kerith Ravine, east of the Jordan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The ravens brought him bread and meat in the morning and in the evening, and he drank from the stream.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After some time the stream dried up because there had been no rain in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to him:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Get up! Go to Zarephath, which belongs to Sidon, and live there. I have commanded a woman there, a widow, to provide for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he got up and went to Zarephath. He came to the city gate, and there he saw a widow gathering sticks. He called to her and said, “Please give me a little water in a jar, so that I can have something to drink.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When she went to get it, he called to her, “Please bring me a piece of bread.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She said, “As surely as the Lord your God lives, I have no food except a handful of flour in a jar and a little olive oil in a pitcher. See, I am gathering a couple of sticks so that I can go and prepare it for myself and my son, so that we can eat it and then die.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said to her, “Do not be afraid. Go and do just as you said. But first make a small loaf of bread for me from the flour and bring it out to me. Then go and make another for you and your son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For this is what the Lord, the God of Israel, says. The jar of flour will not run out and the pitcher of oil will not become empty until the day the Lord sends rain to water the surface of the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So she went and did exactly as Elijah said. He and she, as well as her household, were able to eat for many days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The jar of flour did not run out, and the pitcher of oil did not become empty, just as the Lord had said through Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After these events, the son of the woman who owned the house became ill. The illness became worse until he stopped breathing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then she said to Elijah, “What is the issue between us, man of God? Have you come to remind me of my sins and to kill my son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to her, “Bring your son to me.” Then he took him and carried him to the upstairs room where he was living, and he laid him on his bed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he cried out to the Lord, “O Lord, my God, have you sent tragedy on this woman with whom I am staying by killing her son?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he stretched himself out on the boy three times, and he cried out to the Lord, “O Lord, my God, let this boy’s soul return to his body!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Lord listened to Elijah’s voice, and the boy’s soul returned to his body, and he came to life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Elijah took the boy and brought him down to the house from his upstairs room, and he gave him to his mother.
Elijah said, “See, your son is alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The woman said to Elijah, “Now I know that you are a man of God and that the word of the Lord in your mouth is true.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After a long time, the word of the Lord came to Elijah. (It was during the third year.) He said, “Go and present yourself to Ahab, and I will send rain to water the surface of the ground.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So Elijah went to present himself to Ahab.
Now the drought was severe in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab had summoned his servant Obadiah, the palace administrator. Obadiah was devoted to serving the Lord.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jezebel was exterminating the prophets of the Lord, Obadiah had taken one hundred prophets and kept them hidden in two caves, fifty in each cave, and he provided food and water for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab said to Obadiah, “Go through the land to all the springs and all the streams. Maybe we will find enough grass so that we can keep the horses and mules alive, and we will not have to slaughter the cattle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In order to cover the whole land, they divided it between the two of them. Ahab went one way by himself, and Obadiah went another way by himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Obadiah was on the way, Elijah suddenly met him. Obadiah recognized him and fell on his face and said, “Is that you, my lord Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah answered him, “Yes, it is. Go and tell your master, ‘Elijah is here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Obadiah said, “How have I sinned that you would hand your servant over to Ahab for him to kill me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As surely as the Lord your God lives, there is no country or kingdom where my master has not sent someone to look for you. When they said, ‘He is not here,’ then he made that kingdom and nation swear that they could not find you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now you are telling me, ‘Go, tell your master that Elijah is here.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as I leave you, the Spirit of the Lord will carry you to some place I do not know. When I go to tell Ahab and he then does not find you, he will kill me, even though your servant has been devoted to the Lord since my youth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Has my lord not been told what I did when Jezebel was killing the prophets of the Lord? I kept one hundred of the prophets of the Lord hidden in two caves, fifty in each, and I provided food and water for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now you are saying, ‘Go and tell your master that Elijah is here.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Elijah said to him, “As surely as the Lord of Armies lives, before whom I stand, I will present myself to him today.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Obadiah went to meet Ahab, and he informed him. Then Ahab came to meet Elijah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab saw Elijah, Ahab said to him, “Is that you, the one who brings trouble on Israel?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said, “It is not I who have brought trouble on Israel, but rather you and your father’s house, because you abandoned the Lord’s commandments and followed the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now gather all Israel before me on Mount Carmel, along with the four hundred fifty prophets of Baal and the four hundred prophets of Asherah, who eat at Jezebel’s table.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab sent word to all the people of Israel, and he assembled the prophets on Mount Carmel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to all the people, “How long will you stagger around on two crutches? If the Lord is God, follow him. If Baal is God, follow him.” But the people did not answer him a single word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to the people, “I am the only one left of the Lord’s prophets, but the prophets of Baal total four hundred fifty men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Provide two bulls for us. Let them choose one bull for themselves and cut it up and place it on the firewood, but they are not to light the fire. I will prepare the other bull and place it on the firewood, but I will not light the fire.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then you will call on the name of your god, and I will call on the name of the Lord. The god who answers with fire, he is God.”
All the people said, “This proposal is good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to the prophets of Baal, “Choose for yourselves one bull, and you go first because there are so many of you. Call on the name of your god. But do not light the fire.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they took the bull which had been given to them and prepared it. Then they called on the name of Baal from morning until noon, “Baal! Answer us!” But there was not a sound. No one answered. So they staggered around the altar which they had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When noon came, Elijah mocked them: “Shout louder! He is a god, isn’t he? He may be deep in thought or busy or on a journey. Perhaps he is asleep and will wake up!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they cried out with a loud voice, and according to their practice they cut themselves with daggers and spears until their blood flowed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After noon, they kept up a prophetic frenzy until the time of the evening sacrifice, but there was no sound. No one answered. There was no response.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to all the people, “Come here to me.” So they came to him, and he repaired the altar of the Lord, which had been torn down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah took twelve stones, one for each of the tribes of the sons of Jacob, to whom the word of the Lord had come and had proclaimed, “Your name shall be Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built the stones into an altar in the name of the Lord. Around it he made a trench big enough to hold about twenty-five pounds of seed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He arranged the wood, cut up the bull, and placed it on the wood.
Then he said, “Fill four jars with water and pour it on the sacrifice and on the wood.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he said, “Do it again.” So they did it again. Then he said, “Do it a third time.” So they did it a third time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The water flowed all around the altar. It even filled the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the time of the evening sacrifice had arrived, Elijah the prophet stood up and said, “O Lord, the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, let it be known this day that you are God in Israel and that I am your servant and that I have done all these things by your word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Answer me, Lord! Answer me so that this people will know that you, O Lord, are God and that you are turning their hearts back to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fire from the Lord fell on the sacrifice and on the wood, the stones, and the dirt. It even licked up the water in the trench.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the people saw this, they fell on their knees and said, “The Lord, he is God! The Lord, he is God!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah said to them, “Seize the prophets of Baal! Do not let a single one of them escape!” So they seized them, and Elijah brought them down to the Kishon River and slaughtered them there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Elijah said to Ahab, “Go up, eat and drink, for I hear the sound of a heavy rainstorm.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab went to eat and drink, but Elijah went up to the top of Mount Carmel. He bent down to the ground and put his face between his knees.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said to his servant, “Go up and look toward the sea.”
So his servant went up and looked, and he said, “There is nothing.”
But seven times Elijah told him, “Go again.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
On the seventh time the servant said, “There is a cloud as small as a man’s hand rising from the sea.”
Then Elijah said to him, “Go up and tell Ahab, ‘Hitch up your chariot and go down so that the rain does not stop you.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Meanwhile, the skies got dark with clouds and wind, and there was a heavy rain. So Ahab got into his chariot and went to Jezre’el.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the hand of the Lord was on Elijah, and he hiked up his garments around his waist and ran ahead of Ahab until he came to Jezre’el.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahab told Jezebel everything that Elijah had done, including the fact that he had killed all their prophets with the sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jezebel sent a messenger to say to Elijah, “May the gods punish me severely and even double it, if by this time tomorrow I have not made your life like one of theirs.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elijah was afraid, and he ran for his life. He went to Beersheba, which belongs to Judah, and he left his servant there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he himself went a day’s journey into the wilderness. There he sat down under a broom tree, where he prayed that he would die. He said, “I’ve had enough, Lord. Take my life, for I am no better than my fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he lay down and went to sleep under the broom tree.
Suddenly an angel touched him and said, “Get up and eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he looked around, and near his head there was a loaf of bread baking on coals and a jar of water, so he ate and drank, and then he lay down again.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord came back a second time and touched him and said, “Get up and eat, because the journey is too much for you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he got up and ate and drank. Then, with the strength gained from that food, he walked for forty days and forty nights to Horeb, the mountain of God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He came to a cave and spent the night there.
Then the word of the Lord suddenly came to him, saying, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Armies, but the people of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord said, “Go out and stand on the mountain in the presence of the Lord, for the Lord is passing by.” Then a great and powerful wind tore the mountains and shattered rocks before the Lord, but the Lord was not in the wind.
After the wind came an earthquake, but the Lord was not in the earthquake.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
After the earthquake there was a fire, but the Lord was not in the fire.
After the fire there was a soft, whispering voice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Elijah heard it, he wrapped his face in his cloak, and he went out and stood at the entrance to the cave. Then a voice came to him and said, “Why are you here, Elijah?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “I have been very zealous for the Lord, the God of Armies, but the people of Israel have abandoned your covenant. They have torn down your altars and killed your prophets with the sword. I alone am left, and they are seeking to take my life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Lord said to him, “Go back the way you came and go to the Wilderness of Damascus. When you get there, you are to anoint Hazael as king over Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will also anoint Jehu son of Nimshi as king over Israel and Elisha son of Shaphat from Abel Meholah as prophet in your place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whoever escapes the sword of Hazael, Jehu will kill, and whoever escapes the sword of Jehu, Elisha will kill.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have preserved in Israel seven thousand whose knees have not bent to Baal and whose lips have not kissed him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elijah went from there and found Elisha son of Shaphat. Elisha was doing the plowing with twelve teams of oxen in front of him, and he himself was driving the twelfth team. Elijah crossed over to him and threw his cloak over him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Elisha left the oxen and ran after Elijah. He said, “Let me kiss my father and my mother good-bye! Then I will follow you.”
Then Elijah said, “Go back! For what have I done to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Elisha turned back from following him. Then he took the team of oxen and slaughtered them. Using the equipment from the oxen as fuel, he cooked the meat and gave it to the people, and they ate. Then he got up, followed Elijah, and served him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ben Hadad king of Aram, along with thirty-two kings, mobilized his whole army with their horses and chariots. He went up and laid siege to Samaria and fought against it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sent messengers to Ahab king of Israel in the city,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: who said to him, “This is what Ben Hadad says. Your silver and your gold are mine. The best of your wives and your children are mine.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, “Just as you have said, my lord the king, I and all that I own are yours.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messengers came a second time and said, “This is what Ben Hadad says. I did indeed send word to you, saying, ‘You must give me your silver and your gold and your wives and your children.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So at this time tomorrow, I will send my servants to you, and they will search your palace and the houses of your officials, and they will gather up everything that you value and take it away.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel summoned all the elders of the land. “See how this man is looking for trouble. When he sent for my wives and my children, my silver and my gold, I did not refuse him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the elders and all the people said to him, “Do not listen and do not agree to this!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he told Ben Hadad’s messengers, “Say this to your lord the king. Everything which you demanded of your servant the first time, I will do, but this thing I cannot do.” So the messengers brought his message back to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ben Hadad sent word to him: “May the gods punish me severely and even double it, if the dust left from Samaria will be enough to give a handful to each of those who follow me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel answered, “Tell him that someone who is putting his armor on should not boast like someone who is taking it off.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he heard this message, Ben Hadad and his kings were in their tents drinking. He said to his servants, “Get ready!” and they took up positions against the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But then, at that time, a prophet came to Ahab king of Israel and said, “This is what the Lord says. Do you see all of this huge horde? Look, I am giving it into your hands today. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Ahab said, “Through whom will this happen?”
The prophet answered, “This is what the Lord says. It will be through the young officers from the provinces.”
He said, “Who will start the battle?”
He said, “You will.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Ahab inspected the young officers from the provinces and found that there were two hundred thirty-two. After inspecting them he inspected the whole army. The Israelites numbered seven thousand men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They marched out at noon while Ben Hadad was getting drunk in his tent, along with the thirty-two kings who were supporting him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the young officers from the provinces marched out first. Ben Hadad sent out scouts, who told him, “Men are marching out of Samaria!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ben Hadad said, “If they have come out for peace, take them alive! Even if they have come out for war, take them alive!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when the young officers from the provinces and the army that was with them marched out,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: each of them killed his opponent. Then the Arameans fled, and Israel pursued them. Ben Hadad king of Aram fled on a horse with his charioteers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel marched out and attacked the horses and chariots. He inflicted a great defeat on Aram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Afterward the prophet approached the king of Israel and said to him, “Strengthen your position and consider carefully what you should do, because next spring the king of Aram will attack you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Aram’s officials said to him, “Their gods are gods of the hills. That is why they defeated us. But if we fight them on the plain, we will certainly defeat them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now do this. Remove the kings from their positions as field commanders, and replace them with military officers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then raise an army like the army you lost—horse for horse and chariot for chariot. Then if we fight them on the plain, we will certainly defeat them.” The king listened to them and did what they recommended.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When spring came, Ben Hadad mobilized the army of Aram and went up to Aphek to wage war against Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites also were mobilized and given provisions, and they went out to confront the Arameans. The Israelites camped across from them, like two small flocks of goats, while the Arameans filled the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the man of God approached and said to the king of Israel, “This is what the Lord says. Because the Arameans said, ‘The Lord is a god of the hills, but not a god of the valleys,’ I will give all of this huge horde into your hands. Then you will know that I am the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they camped opposite each other for seven days. On the seventh day the battle was joined by both armies. The Israelites struck down the Arameans—one hundred thousand foot soldiers in one day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The survivors fled to the city of Aphek, and the wall fell on twenty-seven thousand of the survivors. Ben Hadad also fled and went into the city, to an inner room.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his officials said to him, “Look, we have heard that the kings of the house of Israel are merciful. So let us put sackcloth around our waists and ropes around our heads and go out to the king of Israel. Maybe he will spare your life.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So they wrapped sackcloth around their waists and put ropes on their heads, and they went to the king of Israel and said, “Your servant, Ben Hadad, says, ‘Please spare my life.’”
Ahab said, “Is he still alive? He is my brother.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The men took this as a good omen, so they quickly latched on to what he said and responded, “Ben Hadad is your brother.”
Then Ahab said, “Go get him.” So Ben Hadad came out to him, and Ahab brought him up into his chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Ben Hadad said to him, “I will return the cities that my father took from your father, and you may put your own trading centers in Damascus, just as my father put them in Samaria.”
Then Ahab said, “Under these terms, I release you.” So he made a treaty with Ben Hadad and let him go.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then by the word of the Lord one of the sons of the prophets said to his neighbor, “Strike me, please.” But the man refused to strike him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he said to him, “Because you did not listen to the voice of the Lord, when you leave me, a lion will kill you.” When he left him, a lion found him and killed him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he found another man and said, “Strike me, please.” The man struck him and wounded him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet went and stood before the king at the road and disguised himself with a bandage over his eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king was passing by, the prophet shouted to the king, “Your servant went out in the middle of the battle. Then someone brought a man to me and said, ‘Guard this man. If you can’t account for him, then it will be your life for his life, or you will have to pay a talent of silver.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But while your servant was busy doing this and that, all of a sudden the man was gone!”
Then the king of Israel said to him, “That is your sentence. You have pronounced it on yourself.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he quickly removed the bandage from his eyes, and the king of Israel recognized that he was one of the prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to the king, “This is what the Lord says. Because you set a man free, whom I had devoted to destruction, it will be your life for his life and your people for his people.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel headed for his palace sullen and angry, and he arrived in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Some time passed after these events.
Naboth from Jezre’el had a vineyard in Jezre’el, next to the palace of Ahab king of Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab said to Naboth, “Give me your vineyard so I can use it as a vegetable garden, because it is beside my house, and I will give you a better vineyard in exchange. Or if you prefer, I will give you the purchase price in silver.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Naboth said to Ahab, “May I be cursed by the Lord, if I were to give you the inheritance from my fathers.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab went to his house sullen and angry because of what Naboth from Jezre’el had said to him, for he had said, “I will not give you the inheritance of my fathers.” Ahab lay down on his bed and turned his face away and would not eat anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his wife Jezebel came to him and said, “Why is your spirit so sullen, and why don’t you eat?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then he told her, “I said to Naboth from Jezre’el, ‘Sell your vineyard to me, or if you prefer, I will give you a vineyard in its place.’ But he said, ‘I will not give you my vineyard.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then his wife Jezebel said to him, “Are you now acting like the king over Israel? Get up! Eat something, and cheer up. I will give you the vineyard of Naboth from Jezre’el.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jezebel wrote letters in Ahab’s name and sealed them with his seal. She sent the letters to the elders and nobles who were living in the city with Naboth.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She wrote in the letters, “Proclaim a fast and then seat Naboth at the head of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Seat two wicked, worthless men opposite him and have them testify, ‘You cursed God and the king!’ Then take him out and stone him to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men of the city—the elders and the nobles who lived there—did exactly as Jezebel had commanded them, exactly as she had written in the letters she had sent them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They proclaimed a fast and then seated Naboth at the head of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought two wicked, worthless men and seated them opposite him. The wicked men testified against Naboth before the people, “Naboth cursed God and the king!” So they took him outside the city and stoned him to death.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they sent word to Jezebel, “Naboth has been stoned to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jezebel heard that Naboth had been stoned to death, she said to Ahab, “Go and take possession of the vineyard of Naboth from Jezre’el, which he refused to sell to you, because Naboth is no longer alive but dead.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahab heard that Naboth was dead, he went and took possession of the vineyard of Naboth from Jezre’el.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah from Tishbe:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Go down to meet Ahab king of Israel, who rules in Samaria. Right now he is in Naboth’s vineyard because he has gone down to take possession of it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You are to tell him: This is what the Lord says. Have you committed murder and seized this man’s property?
Then you will say to him: This is what the Lord says. In the place where dogs licked Naboth’s blood, dogs will lick your blood also.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Ahab said to Elijah, “Have you found me, my enemy?”
Elijah said, “I have found you, because you sold yourself to do evil in the eyes of the Lord, who says,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘I am bringing disaster against you, and I will burn you up. I will cut off from Ahab in Israel all those who urinate against the wall, both bound and free.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will make your house like the house of Jeroboam son of Nebat and like the house of Ba’asha son of Ahijah, because you have provoked me to anger and caused Israel to sin.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Concerning Jezebel the Lord says, ‘Dogs will eat Jezebel by the wall of Jezre’el.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The dead who belong to Ahab in the city the dogs will eat, and the dead in the country the birds of the air will eat.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There had never been anyone like Ahab, who sold himself to do evil in the eyes of the Lord, incited by his wife Jezebel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He committed obscene acts by following filthy idols, like everything that the Amorites had done, for which the Lord drove them out before the people of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when Ahab heard these words, he cried out and tore his clothes. He put on sackcloth and fasted. He slept in sackcloth and went around in a subdued manner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the word of the Lord came to Elijah from Tishbe, saying,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Have you seen how Ahab has humbled himself before me? Because he has humbled himself before me, I will not bring this disaster during his days, but during the days of his son I will bring disaster upon his house.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Three years went by without any warfare between Aram and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year Jehoshaphat king of Judah went down to visit the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to his officials, “Don’t you know that Ramoth Gilead belongs to us? But we have done nothing to take it from the king of Aram.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he said to Jehoshaphat, “Will you come with me to wage war at Ramoth Gilead?”
Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “I am like you. My people are like your people. My horses are like your horses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat also said to the king of Israel, “First seek the word of the Lord.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel assembled the prophets, four hundred men, and he said to them, “Should I go up to make war at Ramoth Gilead or should I refrain?”
They said, “Go up, for the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat said, “Is there no longer a prophet of the Lord here who can inquire of the Lord for us?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “There is one man who could inquire of the Lord for us, but I hate him because he does not prophesy anything good about me, but only bad. He is Micaiah son of Imlah.”
Jehoshaphat said, “The king should not talk like that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel summoned one of his court officials and said, “Quickly bring Micaiah son of Imlah here.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah were seated, each on his own throne, arrayed in their robes. They were sitting by the threshing floor at the entrance to the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying before them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah son of Kena’anah had made iron horns for himself, and he said, “This is what the Lord says. With these you will gore Aram to death.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the prophets were prophesying in this same way: “Go up to Ramoth Gilead and triumph, for the Lord will give it into the hand of the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger who was sent to summon Micaiah said to him, “Pay attention to the words of the prophets. With one mouth they are promising good things to the king. Let your words be like the words of one of them and say something good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Micaiah said, “As surely as the Lord lives, whatever the Lord says to me, that is what I will say.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then he came to the king, and the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we go up to make war on Ramoth Gilead, or should we refrain?”
He answered him, “Go up and triumph, for the Lord will give them into the hand of the king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king said to him, “How many times must I make you swear that you will tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the Lord?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah said, “I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains like sheep that have no shepherd, and the Lord said, ‘They have no masters. Each one should return to his home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you that he does not prophesy anything good about me, but only bad?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Micaiah said:
Now hear this word from the Lord.
I saw the Lord sitting on his throne, and the whole army of heaven was standing around him, on his right and on his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then the Lord said, “Who will entice Ahab so that he goes up and falls at Ramoth Gilead?”
One spirit said this. Another one said that.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Finally a spirit came and stood before the Lord and said, “I will entice him.”
The Lord said to him, “How?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said, “I will go and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.”
Then the Lord said, “You will entice him successfully. Go and do it.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now look! The Lord has put a lying spirit into the mouths of all these prophets of yours, for the Lord has decreed disaster for you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zedekiah son of Kena’anah came up and struck Micaiah on his cheek and said, “Where is this pathway on which the spirit of the Lord has traveled from me to speak to you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “Listen to me. You will see it on the day you go into the inner room to hide.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel said, “Seize Micaiah and take him back to Amon, the administrator of the city, and to Joash son of the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then say, ‘This is what the king says. Put this man in prison and feed him nothing more than bread and water until I come back safely.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Micaiah said, “If you ever come back safely, then the Lord has not spoken through me.” Then he said, “Hear this, you people, all of you!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramoth Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself when I go into the battle, but you wear your robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Aram had ordered his thirty-two chariot commanders, “Do not fight with anyone small or great, but only against the king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “That is the king of Israel!” They turned to fight against him, and Jehoshaphat cried for help.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders realized that he was not the king of Israel, they stopped pursuing him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But a man shot an arrow at random and struck the king of Israel in the seam between two parts of his armor.
So Ahab said to his chariot driver, “Turn around and take me out of the battle, because I have been wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The battle went on all that day, and the king was propped up in his chariot facing Aram. He died in the evening, and the blood from his wound ran down onto the floor of the chariot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then, as the sun was going down, a cry went up through the army: “Every man to his own city and every man to his own land!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king died, and they brought him to Samaria, and they buried the king in Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They washed the chariot at the pool of Samaria, and dogs licked up his blood, and the prostitutes bathed there, in fulfillment of the word which the Lord had spoken.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Ahab’s acts and everything he did, and the ivory house he built, and all the cities he built, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahab rested with his fathers. Then his son Ahaziah became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat son of Asa became king over Judah in the fourth year of Ahab king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was thirty-five years old when he became king, and he ruled in Jerusalem for twenty-five years. The name of his mother was Azubel daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat walked in all the ways of his father Asa. He did not turn from them. He did what is right in the eyes of the Lord. But the high places were not removed. The people were still sacrificing and burning incense on the high places.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was at peace with the king of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As for the rest of Jehoshaphat’s acts, the mighty deeds which he did, and the wars he fought, are they not written in the annals of the kings of Judah?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He removed from the land the rest of the male shrine prostitutes who remained from the days of his father Asa.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no king in Edom, but rather a governor represented the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat constructed trading ships to go to Ophir for gold, but they never set out, because the ships were wrecked at Ezion Geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Ahaziah son of Ahab said to Jehoshaphat, “Let my servants go with your servants in ships,” but Jehoshaphat was not willing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat rested with his fathers and was buried with his fathers in the city of his father David. Then his son Jehoram became king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah son of Ahab became king of Israel in Samaria in the seventeenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah. He ruled over Israel for two years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil in the eyes of the Lord and walked in the ways of his father and in the ways of his mother and in the ways of Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He served Baal and bowed down to him, and he provoked the Lord, the God of Israel, to anger in all the same ways that his father did.
verses.speaker: Narrator
